sn22.79:4.2: “Mendicants, whatever ascetics and brahmins recollect many kinds of past lives, all recollect the five grasping aggregates, or one of them.
sn22.79:4.4: ‘This is how form was in the past.’
sn22.79:4.5: Recollecting thus, it’s only form that they recollect.
sn22.79:4.11: Recollecting thus, it’s only consciousness that they recollect.
sn22.79:5.1: And why do you call it form?
sn22.79:5.2: It’s inflicted; that’s why it’s called ‘form’.
sn22.79:5.4: Inflicted by cold, heat, hunger, and thirst, and tormented by the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles.
sn22.79:5.5: It’s inflicted; that’s why it’s called ‘form’.
sn22.79:6.1: And why do you call it feeling?
sn22.79:6.2: It feels; that’s why it’s called ‘feeling’.
sn22.79:6.4: It feels pleasure, pain, and neutral.
sn22.79:6.5: It feels; that’s why it’s called ‘feeling’.
sn22.79:7.1: And why do you call it perception?
sn22.79:7.2: It perceives; that’s why it’s called ‘perception’.
sn22.79:7.4: It perceives blue, yellow, red, and white.
sn22.79:7.5: It perceives; that’s why it’s called ‘perception’.
sn22.79:8.1: And why do you call them choices?
sn22.79:8.2: Choices produce conditioned phenomena; that’s why they’re called ‘choices’.
sn22.79:8.3: And what are the conditioned phenomena that they produce?
sn22.79:8.4: Form is a conditioned phenomenon; choices are what make it into form. Feeling is a conditioned phenomenon; choices are what make it into feeling. Perception is a conditioned phenomenon; choices are what make it into perception. Choices are conditioned phenomena; choices are what make them into choices. Consciousness is a conditioned phenomenon; choices are what make it into consciousness.
sn22.79:8.5: Choices produce conditioned phenomena; that’s why they’re called ‘choices’.
sn22.79:9.1: And why do you call it consciousness?
sn22.79:9.2: It cognizes; that’s why it’s called ‘consciousness’.
sn22.79:9.4: It cognizes sour, bitter, pungent, sweet, hot, mild, salty, and bland.
sn22.79:9.5: It cognizes; that’s why it’s called ‘consciousness’.

sn22.79:15.1: This is called a noble disciple who gets rid of things and doesn’t accumulate them;
sn22.79:15.2: who gives things up and doesn’t grasp them;
sn22.79:15.3: who discards things and doesn’t amass them;
sn22.79:15.4: who dissipates things and doesn’t get clouded by them.
sn22.79:15.5: And what things do they get rid of and not accumulate?
sn22.79:15.6: They get rid of form and don’t accumulate it.
sn22.79:15.11: And what things do they give up and not grasp?
sn22.79:15.12: They give up form and don’t grasp it.
sn22.79:15.17: And what things do they discard and not amass?
sn22.79:15.18: They discard form and don’t amass it.
sn22.79:15.23: And what things do they dissipate and not get clouded by?
sn22.79:15.24: They dissipate form and don’t get clouded by it.

sn22.79:16.7: When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.

sn22.79:17.1: This is called a mendicant who neither gets rid of things nor accumulates them, but remains after getting rid of them. They neither dissipate things nor get clouded by them, but remain after dissipating them.

sn22.79:17.3: They neither get rid of nor accumulate form, but remain after getting rid of it.

sn22.79:17.9: They neither give up nor grasp form, but remain after giving it up.

sn22.79:17.13: consciousness, but remain after giving it up.
sn22.79:17.14: And what things do they neither discard nor amass, but remain after discarding them?
sn22.79:17.15: They neither discard nor amass form, but remain after discarding it.

sn22.79:17.26: When a mendicant’s mind is freed like this, the gods together with Indra, Brahmā, and Pajāpati worship them from afar:
sn22.79:18.2: Homage to you, O highest of persons!
